awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Strengthening Wi-Fi Network Wide
awd_abstract_narration:
Wi-Fi has emerged as the technology of choice for Internet access. Thus, virtually every smartphone or tablet is now equipped with a Wi-Fi card. Concurrently, and as a means to maximize spectral efficiency, Wi-Fi radios are becoming increasingly complex and sensitive to wireless channel conditions. The prevalence of Wi-Fi networks, along with their adaptive behaviors, makes them an ideal target for denial of service attacks at a large, infrastructure level.

This project aims to comprehensively investigate the resiliency of Wi-Fi networks to smart attacks, and to design and implement robust solutions capable of resisting or countering them. The project additionally focuses on harnessing new capabilities of Wi-Fi radios, such as multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) antennas, to protect against powerful adversaries. The research blends theory with experimentation and prototyping, and spans a range of disciplines including protocol design and analysis, coding and modulation, on-line algorithms, queuing theory, and emergent behaviors.

The anticipated benefits of the project include: (1) a deep understanding of threats facing Wi-Fi along several dimensions, via experiments and analysis; (2) a set of mitigation techniques and algorithms to strengthen existing Wi-Fi networks and emerging standards; (3) implementation into open-source software that can be deployed on wireless network cards and access points; (4) security training of the next-generation of scientists and engineers involved in radio design and deployment.

por.por_cntn:
New generations of Wi-Fi radios are increasingly complex and sophisticated. These radios optimize their performance by sensing the environment and accordingly adapting their physical layer parameters (e.g., center frequency, bit rate, and modulation) in real-time. This high level of sensitivity of Wi-Fi radios was however designed for non-adversarial scenarios, and therefore makes them vulnerable to targeted, yet stealthy, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.

 

This collaborative research effort between Northeastern University (PI: Guevara Noubir) and Boston University (PI: David Starobinski), comprehensively investigated the resiliency of Wi-Fi networks to sophisticated DoS attacks, and the design and implementation of robust mitigation solutions. The research blends theory with experimentation and prototyping, and consisted of three main thrusts: vulnerability assessment, modeling, and counter-measures. The team investigated several attacks spanning the physical layer to the network layer.

 

At the physical and link layers, the team analyzed the resiliency of OFDM mechanisms underlying Wi-Fi standards IEEE 802.11 a/g/n to smart jamming. Some of the key results derive from the analysis of the structure of the combined interleaver/convolutional coding scheme of 802.11a/g/n within OFDM, and identification of patterns that can be exploited. An analytical and experimental evaluation of the performance of the best cross-layer jammer, and its implementation complexity, demonstrated that an adversary can block Wi-Fi communications at an energy cost nearly five orders of magnitude less than the communicating nodes.  We demonstrated that such attacks can already be implemented on low-cost SDR platforms such as the HackRF. We developed efficient counter-measures that remove any advantage of cross-layer attacks aware of the physical layer design. As part of the mitigations, the team proposed cryptographic interleaving techniques, game-theoretic rate adaptation strategies, and a physical layer extension based on Filter Bank Multi Carrier (FBMC) communications to provide agility and withstand smart jamming.

 

As part of the research activities, the team noted that key to an extensive evaluation of Wi-Fi protocols vulnerabilities and mitigation techniques, is the availability of a flexible instrumentation platform. However, despite the central role of Wi-Fi in today's wireless communications systems, there was still no platform available to the research community to analyze Wi-Fi networks from the physical layer to the network layer with the precision that it deserves. In order to experimentally and extensively investigate IEEE 802.11 vulnerabilities, we developed an open source Wi-Fi implementation that can transmit and receive all IEEE 802.11abg packets (reaching 54Mbps rates with QAM64 modulation and with 3/4 coding rate).

 

At the link and network layer, the team investigated cascading DoS attacks to assess whether spatial coupling of spectrum sharing mechanisms (such as the CSMA/CA protocol used in Wi-Fi) can be exploited by a few malicious nodes to induce spatial congestion of the spectrum and impact an entire (multi-hop) network. The team validated the conjecture that spatial coupling induced by hidden nodes or rate adaptation mechanisms can be exploited to trigger cascading DoS attacks and render specific network topologies unstable. The investigation has incorporated analysis, simulation, and experimental evaluations. The significance of this research is as follows. If a successful cascading DoS attacks can be launched, it means that an adversary can remotely perform a jamming attack on a wireless network (that is the jammer does not need to have a direct physical link to the victim, in contrast to all existing jamming attacks). Moreover, the jammer can be protocol-compliant, that is, it does not need to violate any spectrum access rules. The results of this work were presented at the IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (CNS) 2016, where it was awarded the ?best paper?.
